current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
Recognizing the City of Erie, Pennsylvania,
		  for its critical role in the development and construction of the fleet of
		  Commodore Oliver Hazard Perry during the War of 1812.

sponsor.#tail:
submitted the
			 following resolution; which was referred to the

text.#text:
honors the City
			 of Erie, Pennsylvania, for its role in the development and construction of the
			 fleet of Commodore Oliver Hazard Perry during the War of 1812; and

recognizes the
			 historical significance of the construction of the fleet of Commodore Perry and
			 the consequent victory of the United States in the Battle of Lake Erie.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
as an ideal location
			 for the construction of a naval fleet;

text.#text:
Whereas the City of Erie, Pennsylvania, due to its
			 abundant resources and strategic positioning, was recommended by shipbuilder
			 Daniel Dobbins to the United States

Whereas the victory by the United States over Great
			 Britain in the Battle of Lake Erie on September 10, 1813, was a crucial victory
			 for the United States during the War of 1812, and ensured that the United
			 States maintained control over Lake Erie for the duration of the war;

Whereas the success of the fleet of Commodore Oliver
			 Hazard Perry in the Battle of Lake Erie helped to facilitate the important
			 victory of General William Henry Harrison at the Battle of the Thames, as well
			 as other military actions of the United States throughout the War of
			 1812;

Whereas the City of Erie honors the legacy of Commodore
			 Perry through the Perry Monument at Presque Isle State Park; and

Whereas the City of Erie this year is recognizing the
			 200th anniversary of the Battle of Lake Erie: Now, therefore, be it

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}title.#text: 113 SRES 155 IS: Recognizing the City of Erie, Pennsylvania, for its critical role in the development and construction of the fleet of Commodore Oliver Hazard Perry during the War of 1812.
